process.title: Month 1/2
process.subtitle: Pruning & Preparation
description: After the last harvest, trees are pruned to remove old branches and encourage new growth.
The soil is enriched with organic compost and fertilizers.
Pest and disease control measures are applied before the growing season begins.

process.title: Month 3/4
process.subtitle: Flowering Stage
description: Guava trees start blooming, producing small white flowers.
Natural pollinators (bees, butterflies) help with pollination.
Some farmers practice hand-pollination to improve fruit set.

process.title: Month 5/6
process.subtitle: Fruit Development Begins
description: Small guava fruits start forming after successful pollination.
Thinning is done to ensure the best fruits receive adequate nutrients.
Protective fruit bagging is applied to prevent insect damage.

process.title: Month 7/8
process.subtitle: Fruit Growth & Maturation Begins
description: Guavas continue to grow and mature, changing color depending on the variety.
Trees require consistent watering, especially in dry climates.
Nutrient application and pest control measures are continued.

process.title: Month 9/11
process.subtitle: Harvest Season Begins
description: Guavas are manually harvested when they reach the right ripeness, typically when they emit a sweet aroma and slightly soften.
Harvesting occurs in multiple rounds as not all guavas ripen at the same time.
Fruits are sorted, graded, and packed for sale or processing.

process.title: Month 12
process.subtitle: Post-Harvest Processing & Tree Resting Phase
description: Leftover fruits are used for making jams, juices, or dried products.
The trees enter a dormant or low-activity phase before the next cycle begins.
